org.jgrapes.io

Interface Connection

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    DataConnection
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Extension, File, Server, Server.SocketConnection

    public interface Connection
    Represents an I/O connection. I/O connections are bidirectional but asymmetrical. A connection has an initiator that creates and manages the connection and responders that react to the creation of the connection (and other state changes).

    Events related to a connection are usually handled by two different pipelines. One pipeline, accessible only to the initiator, handles the events from initiator component to responder components. The other, made available as a property of the connection, handles the events from responder to initiator. Of course, any pipeline could be used to send events to the initiator component. However, using arbitrary pipelines holds the risk that events aren't delivered in the intended order.

    Author:
    Michael N. Lipp

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Default Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Channel getChannel()
      Returns A channel that can be used to fire connection related events.
      EventPipeline getResponsePipeline()
      Gets an EventPipeline that can be used for events going back to the initiator on this connection.
      default <T extends Event<?>>
      T      		 respond(T event)
      Fires the given event on this connection's channel using the channel's response pipeline.

    • Method Detail

      • getChannel

        Channel getChannel()
        Returns A channel that can be used to fire connection related events. This is usually the initiator component's channel. Providing this channel as part of the connection simplifies the implementation of responder components as they don't need any other means to find out where to send response events to. Of course, if the initiator component has a well known channel, this well known channel may be used directly as well.
        Returns:
        the channel

      • getResponsePipeline

        EventPipeline getResponsePipeline()
        Gets an EventPipeline that can be used for events going back to the initiator on this connection. Consistently using this event pipeline for response events ensures that the events are written in proper sequence.

      • respond

        default <T extends Event<?>> T respond(T event)
        Fires the given event on this connection's channel using the channel's response pipeline. Effectively, respond(someEvent) is a shortcut for getResponsePipeline.add(someEvent, getChannel()).
        Parameters:
        event - the event to fire
        Returns:
        the event (for easy chaining)
